CuPc and F16CuPC

Jan 23, 2026

Molecule of CuPc and F16CuPc

  • https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jphotochem.2025.116397
  • PHYSICAL REVIEW B 77, 035133, 2008
  • J. Phys. Chem. A 2021, 125, 19, 4055–4061
  • J. Phys. Chem. C 2013, 117, 4, 1863–1878
  • J. Chem. Phys. 162, 244708 (2025)
  • J. Chem. Phys. 109, 8218–8224 (1998)

    TDDFT

    \begin{equation} \delta \rho(r,t)=\chi(r,r^\prime,t-t^\prime)\delta v_{ext}(r^\prime,t^\prime) \end{equation}

\begin{equation} \delta \rho (r,t)= \chi_{irr}(r,r^\prime,t-t^\prime)\delta v_{s}(r^\prime,t^\prime) \end{equation}

\begin{equation} \delta v_s(t)=\delta v_{ext}(t)+\delta v_H(t)+\delta v_{xc}(t) \end{equation} \begin{equation} V_{ind}=\delta v_H(t)+\delta v_{xc}(t) \end{equation} \begin{equation} V_{ind}(r)=f_{Hxc}(r-r^\prime)\delta \rho(r^\prime) \end{equation} \begin{equation} \epsilon \chi=\chi_{irr} \end{equation} \begin{equation} \epsilon=\delta-\chi_{irr}f_{Hxc} \end{equation} \begin{equation} \chi=\epsilon^{-1}\chi_{irr} \end{equation} To find the electronic excitattions of the system, we have to determin the poles of the \(\chi\) We can find two different ways in which poles can arise. First, the poles of \(\chi_{irr}\). Second \(\epsilon\) has an zero mode. The first kind is single-particle excitations,wheras the second type is plasmons.

To find the pole of \(\chi\) is equal to find zero mode of \(\chi^{-1}=\chi_{irr}^{-1}\epsilon=\chi_{irr}^{-1}\delta -f_{Hxc}\)

Now we expand those variables in basis set \begin{equation} \delta \rho= P_{ia}\phi_i\phi_a^* + P_{ai}\phi_a\phi_i \end{equation} \begin{equation} \chi_{irr}(\omega)=\frac{\delta n_{st}}{\epsilon_s-\epsilon_t-\omega} \end{equation}

Casida Equation \begin{equation} \begin{pmatrix} A & B \
B & A \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} X
Y \end{pmatrix}

=\omega \begin{pmatrix} X
Y \end{pmatrix} \end{equation}

NTO

Single Particle transition density \begin{equation} T_{ia}=\langle \Psi_{ex}\vert c^\dagger_a c_i \vert \Psi_0\rangle \end{equation} index i occupied orbitals and a virtual orbitals T is $N_o\times N_v$ matrix \begin{equation} T=U\lambda V \end{equation} \begin{equation} \phi_1,\phi_2,\dots \phi_{N_o}=(\psi_1,\cdots,\psi_{N_o})U \end{equation} \begin{equation} \phi_1,\phi_2,\dots \phi_{N_v}=(\psi_1,\cdots,\psi_{N_a})V \end{equation} So there is particle orbital and hole orbitals.and eigenvalue \(\lambda\)
